He Yet he spok and all this was
done in a mystic and awful sil
silence. If his passion subdued him
he locked himself in his room; and
when he wandered restlessly about the
house, it was when every other crea
-ture slept.
It You may easily ^be imagined that
I wearied myself with conjecture to
guess the cause of his sorrow. The solu-
tion that seemed to me the most
probable was that during his resi-
-dence in London he had fallen in
love with some unvo unworthy per-
son, and that his passion mastered.
him although he would not gratify
it: he loved me too well to sacrifise
me to this inclination, and that he
had now visited this house that by
reviving the memory of my mother
whom he so passionately adored he
might weaken the present impres-
sion. This was possible; yet several
